awd_titl_txt: PFI:AIR - TT:  Novel Low-power III-Nitride Heater Cantilever Based Selective VOC Sensor
awd_abstract_narration:
This PFI: AIR Technology Translation project focuses on translating the discovery of novel microcantilever heaters to fill the need for highly sensitive and selective volatile organic compound (VOC) sensors with an ultra-low power requirement.   These VOC sensors are important because of their strong impact on environmental protection and indoor air quality monitoring which has direct influence on human health and well-being.  The project will result in the development of a commercially viable prototype of a novel VOC sensor packaged in the form of a miniaturized handheld device. This VOC sensor has unique features of high sensitivity and selective detection of VOCs individually and in mixtures, and operation at low heater temperature without catalyst coating.   These features provide the advantages of faster and unique detection of VOCs in a complex environment, much lower power consumption, and higher reliability and operational lifetime, when compared to the leading competing pellistor and photo-ionization based sensors currently available in this market space.  

This project addresses the following technology gap(s) as it translates from research discovery toward commercial application. The VOC sensor to be developed will address: (i) the inability of the current technologies to perform selective detection of analytes, (ii) higher operational power requirement due to high heater temperature, and low operational lifetime due to usage of a laser or catalyst coating. A combination of unique features of the proposed VOC sensor, including low heater temperature, lack of catalyst coating, and selective VOC detection utilizing their physical properties, enables it to address the aforementioned limitations of the current technology. In addition, the personnel involved in this project, at both graduate and undergraduate levels, will receive entrepreneurship and technology translation experiences through participation in the project activities directly related to commercialization and mentorship from the industrial partner. 

The project engages Tangidyne Inc. to guide the commercialization aspects of the sensor developed, and provide unique business mentorship to the graduate and undergraduate students involved in this technology translation effort from research discovery toward commercial reality.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in the development of novel detection methodology for volatile organic compounds (VOCs) utilizing heated triangular microcantilevers made of wide bandgap AlGaN/GaN semiconductor heterojunctions with a single or a dual current conducting channel. Microcantilevers, which resemble tiny diving boards, can respond to a variety of physical parameters, such as temperature, electronic charge, electrostatic potential, stress, and mass loading, which can be used to develop extremely sensitive sensors. Due to their low thermal mass, organic vapors can easily interact with them and produce larger change in temperature and hence resistance of the conductive channel, which can be readily detected. In this project, we demonstrated not only highly sensitive but also selective detection of analyte vapor molecules, by utilizing the differences in dipole moment and latent heat of analyte molecules. Utilizing this capability, detection of VOCs down to few tens of ppm has been demonstrated in this project, with estimated ppm levels of detection possible. These sensors were also able to distinguish between similar organic vapors such as toluene, ethanol, hexane, and even between propanol 1 and 2, with very similar properties, which is not possible with any existing miniaturized sensors, especially with that low power consumption.

The project activities have led to significant contributions to the major discipline of electrical engineering, as well as in the related disciplines of Physics and Materials Science.  They have led to better theoretical and experimental understanding of GaN based microelectromechanical (MEM) devices and systems, utilization of these systems for specific detection of volatile organic compounds at very low concentrations. One of the major features of the sensors, which distinguishes them from other existing sensors, is that they can perform detection with ultra-low power, down to few hundred nWs (taking advantage of the small thermal mass of the cantilever, and the specific detection mechanism), which is very important for sensing applications in wearable and handheld devices. This research also resulted in detailed theoretical modeling finite element simulations of the combined thermo-electromechanical response corresponding to analyte vapor interaction. A wide array of significant research results were obtained over several years, which resulted in the publication of 14 journal publications, 1 patent applications, 11 conference presentations, and 1 invited talk.

The project activities also led to very significant technological and educational broader impacts. In terms of technological broader impact, the development of piezotransistive microcantilever based miniaturized surface potential detection methodology has opened up the possibility of detection of a wide range of organic vapors at low concentrations, with good specificity; which can have potential commercial applications in a variety of fields including biomedical detection, industrial monitoring and medical diagnostics. The project also resulted in the training of two postdoctoral researchers, three doctoral students and two Master of Science students. Additionally, eight undergraduate students were trained in this project. The training that the students obtained from this project enabled them to find employment in reputed companies such as Skyworks, II-VI Semiconductors, Eaton corporation, SPAWAR and research position at the Georgia Institute of Technology. The intellectual properties generated from the research has also attracted interest from commercial entities for developing marketable sensor systems. The project also led to the creation of research infrastructure at Clemson university (in terms of specialized equipment and sensor test beds as well as miniaturized multimodal sensor data acquisition and transmission system), knowledge base, and expertise in the PI’s lab, which is expected to lead to further application of this very promising technology in a large variety of existing and emerging areas.

 


Last Modified: 02/28/2022
Modified by: Goutam Koley
